document.title: Supernatural analogues of Beilinson monads

creator.contact: Department of Mathematics, University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI
Department of Mathematics, University of California, Berkeley, CA

abstract.name: Abstract.
abstract.p: We use supernatural bundles to build GL-equivariant resolutions supported on the diagonal of ×PnPn, in a way that extends Beilinson’s resolution of the diagonal. We thus obtain results about supernatural bundles that largely parallel known results about exceptional collections. We apply this construction to Boij–Söderberg decompositions of cohomology tables of vector bundles, yielding a proof of concept for the idea that those positive rational decompositions should admit meaningful categorifications.

document.acknowledgements: DE was partially supported by NSF grant DMS-1302057. SS was supported by a Miller research fellowship.

para.p: Throughout we work over a field k of characteristic zero. In this paper, we use supernatural bundles to produce GL-equivariant resolutions supported along the diagonal of ×PnPn, in a way that extends Beilinson’s resolution of the diagonal. We thus obtain results about supernatural bundles that largely parallel known results about exceptional collections, including analogues of Beilinson monads.

We then apply these resolutions to the study of Boij–Söderberg decompositions of vector bundles. Boij–Söderberg theory shows that the cohomology table of any vector bundle decomposes as a positive rational linear combination of the cohomology tables of supernatural vector bundles. Perhaps the most mysterious question about this theory is whether these numerical decompositions, which very often involve rational coefficients, admit any sort of categorification to the level of vector bundles. We provide an affirmative answer in many cases, showing that a Fourier–Mukai transform with respect to one of our equivariant resolutions naturally clears the denominators and categorifies many of these decompositions.

subsection.title: 1.1Supernatural bundles as a parallel for exceptional bundles
subsection.toctitle: 1.1Supernatural bundles as a parallel for exceptional bundles

para.p: A vector bundle F on Pn is exceptional if Ext*(F,F) is as small as possible, i.e. if

Math.text: dimension@((Ext ^ 0)@(F, F)) = 1 * [ and ] * dimension@((Ext ^ i)@(F, F)) = 0 * [ for ] * i > 0.

para.p: A vector bundle F on Pn is supernatural if it has as little cohomology as possible, i.e. if for each ∈jZ there is at most one i such that ≠⁢Hi(Pn,⁢F(j))0, and if the Hilbert polynomial of F has n distinct, integral roots.

Supernatural bundles were first defined in [ES1, p. 862] (a closely related definition appeared in [HH, p.365]) where they played a key role in the main results of Boij–Söderberg theory, providing the extremal rays of the cone of cohomology tables. In characteristic 0, many supernatural bundles are familiar objects: consider the tautological exact sequence of vector bundles on Pn

Math.text: 0 to O * (- 1) to O ^ (n + 1) to Q to 0

para.p: applying a Schur functor Sλ to Q* gives a supernatural bundle. Moreover, by varying λ and by twisting by line bundles, one gets a supernatural bundle corresponding to each root sequence (see §2 for detailed definitions of root sequences). However, we emphasize that this does not account for all known supernatural bundles. By pushing forward line bundles from a product of projective spaces, one can construct supernatural bundles in any characteristic, and even in characteristic 0 these bundles are generally distinct from the ⁢SλQ* [ES1, §6]; moreover, many supernatural bundles admit nontrivial moduli [ES3, §6].

Although most supernatural bundles fail to be exceptional, there are some immediate commonalities with exceptional vector bundles. To begin with, the basic examples of exceptional collections, namely {⁢O(-i)}=i0n and {⁢Ωi(i)}=i0n, consist entirely of supernatural sheaves. In addition, a chain of root sequences (see §2) determines a sequence of supernatural bundles …,Ei,E+i1,… where ⇔≠Hom(Ei,Ej)0≥ij [BEKS1, Theorem 1.2].
The following theorem parallels known results about exceptional sequences [Be, BGG, GR]. We write :=⁢K0(Pn)Q⊗Z⁢K0(Pn)Q.

para.p: On the one hand, this is a weaker result than the parallel result for exceptional sequences. For instance, any full exceptional collection forms a Z-basis of ⁢K0(Pn), and can be used to resolve OΔ in the derived category (see, for example, [Ca, §3]). Performing a Fourier–Mukai transform with respect to our resolution thus has a cost that is not present when working with Beilinson’s resolution: whereas a Fourier–Mukai transform with respect to a resolution of OΔ is the identity in the derived category, a Fourier–Mukai transform with respect to an appropriate resolution of a higher rank sheaf can introduce a “scalar multiple”.

On the other hand, in contrast with the bundles that arise in exceptional sequences via mutations, we work entirely with simple, familiar bundles: line bundles on the W side, and equivariant bundles of the form ⁢SλQ* on the W⟂ side.
The simplest example of Theorem 1.1 is when =W{⁢O(-i)}=i0n; then =W⟂{⁢Ωi(i)}=i0n and EW is Beilinson’s resolution of the diagonal [Be]. The following is one of the next simplest examples.
On P2, let =W{O,⁢O(-2),⁢O(-3)}. In this case =W⟂{E0,E1,E2} where =E0⁢O(1),=E1⁢(Sym2Q*)(1) and E2=Q*=⁢Ω1(1). We then have:

which resolves a sheaf UW set-theoretically supported on the diagonal copy of P2 in ×P2P2. In fact, if IΔ is the ideal sheaf of the diagonal, then =UW/O×P2P2IΔ2, and the pushforward of UW to either factor is a rank 3 bundle on P2. ∎eg
The following Fourier–Mukai transforms play an essential role in many of our applications. Let ⁢Db(Pn) be the bounded derived category of coherent sheaves on Pn.
For any n and any W, we define the Fourier–Mukai transforms :ΦWi→⁢Db(Pn)⁢Db(Pn) for =i1,2 via:
defn-placeholder

Recall that in [Be], Beilinson uses his resolution of the diagonal to construct two monads for an arbitrary sheaf; the first monad (sometimes referred to as the Beilinson monad) involves the sheaves {⁢Ωi(i)}=i0n and the second monad involves the line bundles {⁢O(-i)}=i0n; see also [AO, EFS] for additional details. Our first application of Theorem 1.1 yields two spectral sequences which provide analogues of these monads for an arbitrary W. We write [F] for the class of a sheaf F in the Grothendieck group ⁢K0(Pn).

p.text: Continue with the notation of Theorem 1.1. Let F be a coherent sheaf on Pn.

Math.text: (Phi ^ W) _ i colon K _ 0 * P ^ n to K _ 0 * P ^ n
N _ W
delimited-[]@((Phi ^ W) _ i * F) = N _ W cdot delimited-[]@(F)
W ^ perpendicular-to

delimited-[]@(F) = (1 / N _ W) * ((sum _ (j = 0)) ^ n)@(((- 1) ^ j * chi * open-interval@(P ^ n, F * (- w _ j))) cdot delimited-[]@(E _ j))

p.text: that categorify each of these expressions. Namely, there are spectral sequences

((widehat@(E)) ^ 1) _ (list@(p, q)) = (H ^ (- p) * open-interval@(P ^ n, F * (- w _ q))) tensor-product E _ q Longrightarrow (Phi ^ W) _ 2 * F

para.p: We also obtain an analogue of the existence of linear resolutions. A 0-regular sheaf F has a linear resolution, i.e. a resolution of the form

Math.text: O ^ (b _ 0) leftarrow O * (- 1) ^ (b _ 1) leftarrow dots leftarrow O * (- n) ^ (b _ n) leftarrow 0

para.p: see for instance [Laz, Proposition 1.8.8]. This can also be shown using Beilinson’s monad in terms of {⁢O(-i)}=i0n.

We generalize this result to arbitrary collections of line bundles as follows. We will say that a sheaf F has a pure resolutionPure resolutions play a central role in Boij–Söderberg theory, where they are, in a certain sense, dual to supernatural vector bundles [ES1, EE]. of type (w0,w1,…,wn) if there exists a resolution of the form:

Math.text: O * (- w _ 0) ^ (b _ 0) leftarrow O * (- w _ 1) ^ (b _ 1) leftarrow dots leftarrow O * (- w _ n) ^ (b _ n) leftarrow 0.

para.p: For an arbitrary collection =W{⁢O(-w0),⁢O(-w1),…,⁢O(-wn)}, it is not hard to find examples where F cannot have a resolution in terms of these line bundles. In particular, there can be no such resolution whenever the expression for the class [F] in terms of the [⁢O(-wi)] in ⁢K0(Pn)Q involves non-integral coefficients.

However, Corollary 1.4 shows that the Fourier–Mukai transform ΦW1 simultaneously clears all of the denominators for the expression of [F]. Once this obstruction is removed by ΦW1, we obtain a pure resolution of type (w0,w1,…,wn) of any w0-regular sheaf F.

p.text: Let F be any w0-regular coherent sheaf on Pn and fix any sequence w0<w1<…<wn. Let =W{⁢O(-w0),⁢O(-w1),…,⁢O(-wn)}. Then ⁢ΦW1(F) admits a pure resolution of type (w0,w1,…,wn).

para.p: See also Example 4.3. 1.2Categorified Boij–Söderberg decompositions1.2Categorified Boij–Söderberg decompositions
The cohomology table ⁢γ(F) of a vector bundle F on Pn is a table whose entries record the dimensions of all of the cohomology groups of F:

Math.text: gamma _ (list@(i, j)) * F assign h ^ i * open-interval@(P ^ n, F * j)

para.p: Eisenbud and Schreyer show that the cohomology table of any vector bundle decomposes as a positive rational linear combination of the cohomology tables of supernatural vector bundles [ES1, Theorem 0.5].

If F is the cokernel of a generic matrix ←⁢OP2(-1)5⁢OP2(-2)2, then F is a rank 3 vector bundle on P2. The supernatural bundles :=EQ* and :=E′⁢(Sym2Q*)(1) appear in the Boij–Söderberg decomposition of F, which is given by:
eg
A fundamental mystery raised by this theory is whether these numerical decompositions admit meaningful categorifications to the level of vector bundles.

There is an obvious obstacle to categorifying (1.7): the non-integral coefficient. Naively, we might replace F by F⊕3 and hope for a splitting ≅F⊕3⊕E⊕3E′, but that line of thinking has not produced meaningful categorifications. There has been work on categorification on the dual side of Boij–Söderberg theory involving Betti tables [EES], but those results never involve cases with a non-integral coefficient.
There is also a more subtle obstacle to categorifying Boij–Söderberg decompositions which is given by the fact that supernatural bundles themselves can have moduli.

The Fourier–Mukai transform Φ2W can address both of these obstacles. The sheaf UW is a twisted Ulrich sheaf (see Proposition 4.2), and thus—as already observed in Corollary 1.4—the transform ΦW2 has an effect similar to scalar multiplication. Moreover, we will see in Corollary 1.10 that ΦW2 also addresses the second obstacle by entirely collapsing the moduli of certain supernatural bundles.
Returning to Example 1.6, the transformed bundle ⁢Φ1W(F) splits as:

Math.text: (Phi _ 1) ^ W * F approximately-equals E ^ (direct-sum 3) direct-sum E ^ prime

para.p: This implies (1.7), yielding the desired categorification. See Example 7.1 for details. ∎eg
This example is a special case of the following result.

p.text: Continue with the notation of Theorem 1.1. Let F be a vector bundle on Pn and assume that all summands in the Boij–Söderberg decomposition of F come from W⟂, i.e. assume that we have an expression

Math.text: gamma * F = ((sum _ (i = 0)) ^ n)@(a _ i * gamma * E _ i * [ where ] * a _ i) element-of Q _ (absent >= 0)

p.text: Then =⁢γ(⁢ΦW2(F))⁢NWγ(F), and the transformed bundle ⁢ΦW2(F) has a filtration

Math.text: 0 = F _ (- 1) subset-of-or-equals F _ 0 subset-of-or-equals F _ 1 subset-of-or-equals dots subset-of-or-equals F _ n = (Phi ^ W) _ 2 * F
F _ i / F _ (i - 1) approximately-equals (E _ i) ^ (direct-sum N _ W cdot a _ i)

para.p: We view Theorem 1.9 as a proof of concept for the idea that the positive rational Boij–Söderberg decompositions of cohomology tables should admit meaningful categorifications. Namely, the Fourier–Mukai transform ΦW2 provides a novel mechanism for introducing a scalar multiple and clearing denominators, and the spectral sequence for ΦW2 from Corollary 1.4 is based on supernatural bundles. In fact, Theorem 1.9 yields the first known categorification of Boij–Söderberg decompositions that genuinely make use of the Q-coefficients.

Even the simplest case of Theorem 1.9 is surprising, at least to the authors. For instance, as remarked earlier, supernatural bundles with a given root sequence can have nontrivial moduli [ES3, §6]. This moduli collapses entirely after applying ΦW2:

p.text: Let F be any supernatural sheaf with root sequence ∖{-w0,-w1,…,-wn}{-wi}. Then ⁢ΦW2(F) is a direct sum of copies of the equivariant supernatural sheaf Ei. More precisely, setting =m⋅NWrankFrankEi, we have ≅⁢ΦW2(F)Ei⊕m.

para.p: Theorem 1.9 does not apply to a general vector bundle, as for many vector bundles, the summands in the Boij–Söderberg decomposition will not come from a single W⟂. See Remark 7.3 for brief comments about some of the challenges in generalizing Theorem 1.9.
We thank David Eisenbud and Frank-Olaf Schreyer for discussions that inspired this work. We also thank İzzet Coşkun, Brendan Hassett, Jack Huizenga, and Matthew Woolf for useful discussions.
Fix a field k of characteristic zero.

The Schur functor Sλ is defined for any partition λ=(λ1≥λ2≥⋯≥0). It can be applied to any vector bundle E; the result is a vector bundle ⁢SλE. If α=(α1≥…≥αr) is a weakly decreasing sequence and =rankEr, then define =⁢SαE⁢⊗(detE)⊗αrSλE where =λi-αiαr. If ≥αr0, this is consistent with properties of Schur functors. An important property is that ≅(⁢SλE)*⁢SβE where =β(-αr,-α-r1,…,-α1). We refer the reader to [Wey, §2] for details on Schur functors, but we point out that our notation for Schur functors coincides with the notation for Weyl functors, denoted Kλ, used there.

Let =S⁢k[x0,…,xn] and =PnPnk. A degree sequence of length s is a sequence d=(d0,d1,…,ds)∈Z+s1 where <did+i1 for each i. A root sequence for Pn is a sequence =f(f1,…,fn) where >fif+i1 for each i. Although there are more general notions of degree sequence and root sequence in the literature on Boij–Söderberg theory [BS1, ES2, EE, KS], we will not use those notions.

We compare root sequences via the partial order ≤ff′, which holds if ≤fifi′ for all i, and we define a chain (…,f(j),f(+j1),…)∈jZ of root sequences as a collection of root sequences such that <f(j)f(+j1) for all ∈jZ.

Given a root sequence =f(f1,…,fn), a vector bundle E on Pn is a supernatural bundle of type f if for each ∈jZ we have that ≠⁢Hi(Pn,⁢E(j))0 for at most one i, and if =⁢H∙(Pn,⁢E(fj))0 for =j1,…,n. These are the vector bundles with the fewest possible nonzero cohomology groups. Eisenbud and Schreyer have shown the existence of supernatural vector bundles via two separate constructions. The first construction works only in characteristic zero (and was observed by Weyman): if we define a partition μ via =μi+-f1f-+n1ini, then ⁢SμQ is a supernatural bundle of type f [ES1, Theorem 6.2]. A second construction involves the pushforward of a line bundle from a product of projective spaces, and that construction works in arbitrary characteristic [ES1, Theorem 6.1] (see also [BEKS2]).

Given a degree sequence =d(d0,…,ds), a free complex F∙=[F0←F1←⋯←Fs←0] of graded S-modules is a pure resolution of type d if F∙ is acyclic and if ≅Fi⁢S(-di)bi for some >bi0. Boij and Söderberg conjectured that for any degree sequence d, there is a pure resolution of type d that, moreover, resolves a Cohen–Macaulay module [BS2]. This conjecture was proven by Eisenbud, Fløystad, and Weyman in [EFW, Theorems 0.1 and 0.2] in characteristic zero, and by Eisenbud and Schreyer [ES1, Theorem 0.1] in arbitrary characteristic. We will only be interested in the case =sn.

The construction of pure resolutions from [EFW, Theorem 0.1] will be most relevant for us, and we discuss a relative version of that construction. Let E be a vector bundle of rank n over a k-scheme X. Let =ASym(E). Let =d(d0,…,dn) be a degree sequence. For =j0,1,…,n, define partitions =⁢λ(d)j(⁢λ(d)j1,…,⁢λ(d)jn) by

Math.text: lambda * (d ^ j) _ i = cases@(d _ n - d _ (i - 1) - n - i, i less= j, d _ n - d _ i - n - i, i > j)

para.p: If it is clear from context, we will write λj instead of ⁢λ(d)j. The EFW complex of d and E is the following complex of vector bundles on =E*SpecX(A)

Math.text: (A tensor-product S _ (lambda * d ^ 0)) * E leftarrow (A tensor-product S _ (lambda * d ^ 1)) * E leftarrow cdots leftarrow (A tensor-product S _ (lambda * d ^ n)) * E leftarrow 0.
(A tensor-product S _ (lambda * d ^ 0)) * E leftarrow (A tensor-product S _ (lambda * d ^ 1)) * E leftarrow cdots leftarrow (A tensor-product S _ (lambda * d ^ n)) * E leftarrow 0.

para.p: It is an acyclic complex and resolves a Cohen–Macaulay sheaf which is set-theoretically supported in the zero section of E*. Note that the original construction in [EFW] is the case where X is a point and E is a vector space of rank n.
Let V be a vector space of dimension +n1 and let ⁢P(V) be the space of lines. Then we have a tautological exact sequence

Math.text: 0 to O * (- 1) to V tensor-product O to Q to 0.

para.p: Since we will use it a few times, we recall the Borel–Weil–Bott theorem for ⁢P(V) (see [Wey, Corollary 4.1.9]). Given a permutation σ, we define the length of σ to be =⁢ℓ(σ)⁢#{⁢i<j∣⁢σ(i)>σ(j)}. Also, define =ρ(n,-n1,…,1,0). Given a sequence of integers ∈αZ+n1, we define =∙σα-⁢σ(+αρ)ρ.

p.text: Let =α(α1,…,αn) be a weakly decreasing sequence, pick ∈dZ, and set =β(d,α1,…,αn). Then exactly one of the following two situations occur.

Math.text: sigma not-equals id
sigma bullet beta = beta
((S _ alpha * Q ^ *) tensor-product O) * d
gamma = sigma bullet beta

p.text: is a weakly decreasing sequence. Then

Math.text: H ^ (ell * sigma) * open-interval@(P * V, ((S _ alpha * Q ^ *) tensor-product O) * d) = S _ gamma * V ^ *

para.p: Pick a vector space V of dimension +n1 and let =X⁢×⁢P(V)P(V). We have a ⁢GL(V)-equivariant isomorphism =⁢H0(X;⊠⁢O(1)Q)⁢End(V) which can be explicitly obtained by sending ∈ϕ⁢End(V) to the composition

Math.text: (O * (- 1)) boxtimes O to V boxtimes O phi@(rightarrow) O boxtimes V to O boxtimes Q

para.p: So the zero locus of the identity map in ⁢End(V) is the diagonal ⊂Δ⁢P(V)X.
Take =E⊠⁢O(-1)Q* and build (2.2) with d=w=(w0,…,wn). The identity section of E* gives a map →Sym(E)OX; tensoring with it, we get an equivariant complex:

Math.text: ((O * (- absolute-value@(lambda ^ 0))) boxtimes S _ (lambda ^ 0)) * Q ^ * leftarrow ((O * (- absolute-value@(lambda ^ 1))) boxtimes S _ (lambda ^ 1)) * Q ^ * leftarrow cdots leftarrow ((O * (- absolute-value@(lambda ^ n))) boxtimes S _ (lambda ^ n)) * Q ^ * leftarrow 0.

para.p: We define EW as the complex obtained by twisting the above complex by ⁢⊠⁢O(-|λ0|w0)O(-wnn). By the Eagon–Northcott generic perfection theorem [BV, Theorem 3.5], EW is acyclic and it resolves a Cohen–Macaulay sheaf UW which is set-theoretically supported on the diagonal Δ⁢P(V).

The sheaf UW has an action of ⁢GL(V), so its pushforward along either projection →⁢×⁢P(V)P(V)⁢P(V) is homogeneous, and hence is a vector bundle. Furthermore, the pushforward from the support of UW to either ⁢P(V) is exact, so we can calculate the rank of this bundle as the multiplicity of the cokernel of the EFW complex, which is NW (this is implicit in the description of the cokernel given in [EFW, Theorem 3.2(2)], and follows more directly from the description given in [SS, Remark 4.3.3]).

By Borel–Weil–Bott (Theorem 2.3), the sheaf cohomology of ⁢⊗⁢O(d)Sμ(Q*) vanishes if and only if =d-μii for some i, so ⁢Sμ(Q*) is a supernatural vector bundle whose Hilbert polynomial has roots (-μ11,-μ22,…,-μnn). In particular, ⁢⊗⁢Sλj(Q*)O(-wnn) is a supernatural vector bundle whose Hilbert polynomial has roots ∖{-w0,…,-wn}{-wj}. Thus, setting

Math.text: (W ^ perpendicular-to) _ j = E _ j assign ((S _ (lambda ^ j * w) * Q ^ *) tensor-product O) * (w _ n - n)
(W ^ perpendicular-to) _ j = E _ j assign ((S _ (lambda ^ j * w) * Q ^ *) tensor-product O) * (w _ n - n)

para.p: we obtain the desired supernatural bundle. This proves (3). It follows from Borel–Weil–Bott (Theorem 2.3) that =⁢Hi(⁢P(V),⁢Ei(-wi))⁢S⁢μ(W)(V*) and that the cohomology vanishes in other degrees. This proves part of (2).
We now use the cohomology calculation to deduce that W and W⟂ both span a subgroup of ⁢K0(Pn) of index NW. We have a nondegenerate bilinear pairing on ⁢K0(Pn) given by

Math.text: list@(delimited-[]@(E), delimited-[]@(F)) = ((sum _ (i = 0)) ^ n)@((- 1) ^ i * dimension@((Ext ^ i)@(E, F)))

para.p: (nondegeneracy can be proven by observing that on the basis [O],[⁢O(-1)],…,[⁢O(-n)], the Gram matrix is upper unitriangular). First, we show that W is linearly independent in ⁢K0(Pn)Q. Suppose that we have an expression =0∑i⁢ai[⁢O(-wi)]. Applying ⟨-,[Ej]⟩, we get =0⁢ajNW, and so =aj0 for all j. A similar argument shows that W⟂ is linearly independent. Thus W and W⟂ each forms a basis for ⁢K0(Pn)Q.

Now suppose that we have an expression =[F]∑i⁢ai[⁢O(-wi)] where ∈aiQ and F is a vector bundle. Again, we deduce that =aj⁢1NW⟨[F],[Ej]⟩, so ⁢NW[F] is in the Z-span of W for all F. A similar argument applies to W⟂. This finishes the proof of (1) and (2).

Alternatively, to prove that W spans a subgroup of index NW in ⁢K0(Pn), it suffices to prove that for any ∉⁢O(-d)W, we can write ⋅NW[⁢O(d)] as a Z-linear combination of the classes [⁢O(-wi)]. There is a unique j such that wj<d<w+j1 and thus e:=(w0,w1,…,wj,d,w+j1,…,wn)∈Z+n2 is a degree sequence. Using the construction of the EFW complex in the previous section, there is a pure resolution

of type e that resolves a finite length module. The corresponding complex of sheaves ~F∙ on Pn is thus exact. From (2.1), we see that =b+j1dim⁢S⁢μ(W)(k+n1), so =b+j1NW. It follows that ⋅NW[⁢O(-d)] can be written as a Z-linear combination of the classes [⁢O(-wi)] in ⁢K0(Pn). ∎rmk

section.title: 4Properties of UW and the proof of Corollary 1.4
section.toctitle: 4Properties of UW and the proof of Corollary 1.4

para.p: Recall that we use UW to denote the sheaf resolved by EW. Given a finite map :f→XPn we say that a coherent sheaf F on X is an Ulrich sheaf for f if ≅⁢f*FOPnN for some N.
Let ΔW be the scheme-theoretic support of UW. ∎defn-placeholder

p.text: For =i0,…,n, ⁢UW(wi,-wi) is an Ulrich sheaf for :p1→ΔWPn. More precisely, ≅⁢p1⁣*(⁢UW(wi,-wi))OPnNW.

para.p: Since p1ΔW is affine, we have =⁢Rkp1⁣*(⁢UW(wi,-wi))0 for >k0. Also, since -wi is a root of each supernatural bundle Ej for ≠ji, the hypercohomology spectral sequence for computing =⁢Rp1⁣*(⁢UW(wi,-wi))⁢Rp1⁣*(⁢EW(wi,-wi)) consists of a single term E1-i,i=⁢⊠OHi(Pn,⁢Ei(-wi))≅OPnNW (the isomorphism follows from Theorem 1.1(2)). Hence the spectral sequence immediately degenerates yielding ≅⁢p1⁣*(⁢UW(wi,-wi))OPnNW. ∎
We first prove part (3). For =i1 we have
To compute ⁢Φ1(F), we apply ⁢Rp1⁣* to this complex. The hypercohomology spectral sequence for ⁢Rp1⁣* has the form:

Math.text: (E ^ 1) _ (list@(p, q)) = R ^ (- p) * p _ (list@(1, *)) * (((O * (- w _ q)) boxtimes E _ q) tensor-product F) Longrightarrow (Phi ^ W) _ 1 * F

para.p: Using the fact that ≅⁢R-pp1⁣*(⊗⊠⁢O(-wq)EqF)⁢⊗⁢O(-wq)H-p(Pn,⊗EqF), we obtain the statement for =i1. The proof for =i2 is similar.

We next prove part (1). It suffices to prove the statement for ⁢K0(Pn)Q. Proposition 4.2 shows that =⁢ΦW1(⁢O(-wi))⁢O(-wi)NW for =i0,…,n, so we see that ⁢K0(ΦW1) acts as multiplication by NW on each [⁢O(-wi)]. By Theorem 1.1(1), the classes of the ⁢O(-wi) form a basis of ⁢K0(Pn)Q, and it follows that ΦW1 acts as multiplication by NW on all of ⁢K0(Pn)Q.

For ΦW2, we first observe that the ^E1-page of the spectral sequence for ⁢ΦW2(Ei) has a single nonzero term =^E1-i,i⊗⁢Hi(Pn,⁢Ei(-wi))Ei. By Theorem 1.1(2), this is isomorphic to Ei⊕NW, and thus =[⁢ΦW2(Ei)]⋅NW[Ei] for =i0,1,…,n. Since the Ei form a basis of ⁢K0(Pn)Q by Theorem 1.1(2), it follows that ΦW2 acts as multiplication by NW on all of ⁢K0(Pn)Q.

For part (2), we observe that since W and W⟂ are bases of ⁢K0(Pn)Q, the coefficients will be unique. By part (1) of this theorem it suffices to write down an expression for the class of ⁢ΦWi(F). In ⁢K0(Pn), the alternating sum of the terms in a spectral sequence is invariant under turning the page of a spectral sequence. Thus, since the spectral sequence E1p,q abuts to ⁢Φ1W(F), we have

Math.text: delimited-[]@((Phi _ 1) ^ W * F) = (sum _ (list@(p, q)))@((- 1) ^ (p + q) * delimited-[]@((E ^ 1) _ (list@(p, q))))
delimited-[]@((Phi _ 1) ^ W * F)
absent = (sum _ (list@(p, q)))@((- 1) ^ (p + q) * delimited-[]@((E ^ 1) _ (list@(p, q))))
absent = ((sum _ (q = 0)) ^ n)@(((sum _ (p = - n)) ^ 0)@(((- 1) ^ (i + j) * h ^ (- p) * open-interval@(P ^ n, E _ q tensor-product F)) cdot delimited-[]@(O * (- w _ q))))
absent = ((sum _ (q = 0)) ^ n)@(((sum _ (p = - n)) ^ 0)@(((- 1) ^ (i + j) * h ^ (- p) * open-interval@(P ^ n, E _ q tensor-product F)) cdot delimited-[]@(O * (- w _ q))))
absent = ((sum _ (q = 0)) ^ n)@((chi * open-interval@(P ^ n, E _ q tensor-product F)) cdot delimited-[]@(O * (- w _ q)))
absent = ((sum _ (q = 0)) ^ n)@((chi * open-interval@(P ^ n, E _ q tensor-product F)) cdot delimited-[]@(O * (- w _ q)))

para.p: Since =[⁢Φ1W(F)]⋅1NW[F], this yields the statement for W. The statement for W⟂ is similar. ∎
Returning to Example 1.2, let L be a line in P2. Then in ⁢K0(P2)Q we have
Applying the Fourier–Mukai transform ΦW1 categorifies this decomposition, as if we use the spectral sequence E1p,q from Corollary 1.4, then we obtain an exact sequence:

Math.text: 0 leftarrow (Phi ^ W) _ 1 * O _ L leftarrow O ^ 2 leftarrow O * (- 2) ^ 3 leftarrow O * (- 3) leftarrow 0.

para.p: Using W⟂ on the other hand, we have the decomposition

Math.text: delimited-[]@(O _ L) = ((1 / 3) * delimited-[]@(E _ 0) + (1 / 3) * delimited-[]@(E _ 1)) - (2 / 3) * delimited-[]@(E _ 2)

para.p: and a direct computation using the other spectral sequence (plus the fact that Ext1(E1,E0)=⁢H1(Sym2Q)=0) yields an exact sequence:

Math.text: 0 leftarrow (Phi ^ W) _ 2 * O _ L leftarrow E _ 0 direct-sum E _ 1 leftarrow (E _ 2) ^ 2 leftarrow 0.

para.p: eg

section.title: 5The effect of ΦW2 on cohomology tables
section.toctitle: 5The effect of ΦW2 on cohomology tables

para.p: In the situation of Theorem 1.9, we need to prove that =⁢γ(⁢ΦW2(F))⁢NWγ(F). Although ΦW2 acts as scalar multiplication in the Grothendieck group, it is not true that it always acts as scalar multiplication on cohomology tables; see Example 5.2. However, we do have the following semicontinuity statement in general.

p.text: Let F be any coherent sheaf on Pn. Then for all i and all d, we have

Math.text: h ^ i * open-interval@(P ^ n, (Phi ^ W) _ 2 * F * d) >= (N _ W cdot h ^ i) * open-interval@(P ^ n, F * d)

p.text: In the following 3 cases, the above is an equality:

Math.text: d element-of set@(- w _ 0, dots, - w _ n)
d less - w _ n

para.p: A semicontinuity result is the best we can hope for in full generality, in light of examples like the following.
Continue with the notation of Example 1.2. Using the spectral sequence ^E1p,q from Corollary 1.4 to compute =⁢Rp2⁣*UW⁢p2⁣*UW, we get an extension:

Math.text: 0 to O * 1 to p _ (list@(2, *)) * U _ W to Omega ^ 1 * 1 to 0.

para.p: But Ext1(⁢Ω1(1),⁢O(1))=⁢H1(P2,(Ω1)*)=0 and so =⁢p2⁣*UW⊕⁢Ω1(1)⁢O(1). This has the same Hilbert polynomial as O3, but UW is not an Ulrich sheaf for p2. Moreover, the cohomology table of ⁢ΦW2(O) does not equal a scalar multiple of the cohomology table of O3. ∎eg
Our proof of Proposition 5.1 relies on a more detailed analysis of the equivariant extensions—or lack thereof—between certain equivariant bundles. We motivate this discussion with an example.

Recall our notation for the tautological exact sequence 0→⁢O(-1)→⊗VO→Q→0. The equivariant bundle ⊗Sym2(V)O⁢P(V) has a filtration whose quotients are ⁢O(-2), ⊗⁢O(-1)Q, and Sym2(Q). There are two proper equivariant subbundles: ⁢O(-2) and the kernel E of the surjection →Sym2(V)Sym2(Q).
We first consider the subbundle ⁢O(-2), which determines an exact sequence:

Math.text: 0 to O * (- 2) to (Sym ^ 2)@(V) tensor-product O _ (P * V) to W to 0.

para.p: We claim that if you reverse the roles of the subbundle and the quotient bundle in the above extension, then there will be no nontrivial extensions. In other words, we claim that =Ext1(⁢O(-2),W)0; this follows by considering the long exact sequence:

Math.text: cdots to (Ext ^ 1)@(O * (- 2), (Sym ^ 2)@(V)) to (Ext ^ 1)@(O * (- 2), W) to (Ext ^ 2)@(O * (- 2), O * (- 2)) to cdots

para.p: since the outer two terms are zero.
If we consider the other subbundle E then we also have an exact sequence

Math.text: 0 to E to (Sym ^ 2)@(V) tensor-product O _ (P * V) to (Sym ^ 2)@(Q) to 0.

para.p: If we reverse the roles of the subbundle and the quotient bundle, then we get =Ext1(E,Sym2(Q))0, which follows by a similar argument. ∎eg
The splitting observed in the above example holds in general, at least if we restrict our attention to equivariant extensions.

p.text: Pick a partition λ. Let ⊂E⊗⁢Sλ(V)O⁢P(V) be an equivariant subbundle and let F be the quotient bundle. Every ⁢GL(V)-equivariant extension

Math.text: 0 to F to U to E to 0

para.p: Pick a direct sum decomposition =V⊕LW where =dimL1. Let p be the Lie algebra of the stabilizer subgroup in ⁢GL(V) of the point ∈[L]⁢P(V), so ≅p⋉(⁢×⁢gl(W)gl(L))(⊗LW*). Let E and F be the fibers of E and F over [L]. The assignment ↦EE is an equivalence between the category of homogeneous bundles on ⁢P(V) and the category of p-modules. It then suffices to show that =Ext1p(E,F)0. Furthermore, a p-module is the same as a Sym(⊗LW*)-module with a compatible action of ⁢×⁢gl(L)gl(W). We ignore ⁢gl(L) since it only keeps track of the grading.

By ⁢gl(W)-equivariance, both E and F are a direct sum of Schur functors on W. Furthermore, ⁢Sλ(V) has the property that the submodule generated by any ⁢Sμ(W) contains all ⁢Sν(W) where ⊆νμ: this is the graded dual of the cokernel of an EFW complex over Sym(W), and is the quotient of a module of the form ⁢⊗Sym(W)Sα(W), and these modules have this property [SW, Lemma 1.6].
In particular, this is true for E, and so there is no nonzero equivariant map →⊗E(⊗LW*)F. So any equivariant extension of the form 0→F→η→E→0 splits as a p-module. ∎

p.text: Continue with the notation of Theorem 1.1. Fix any ∈dZ. There is a sheaf G on ×PnA1, flat over A1, such that

Math.text: G _ x approximately-equals cases@((Phi _ 1) ^ W * O * d, [if ] * x = 0 element-of A ^ 1, O * d ^ (N _ W), [if ] * x element-of A ^ 1 set-minus set@(0))

para.p: Define ⁢μ(W) as in Theorem 1.1. Let :q→×PnA1Pn be the first projection. If =d-wi for some i, then by the argument in the proof of Corollary 1.4 we have that ≅⁢ΦW1(⁢O(d))⁢⊗⁢S⁢μ(W)(V)O(d) as an equivariant module and we take :=G⁢q*(⁢⊗⁢S⁢μ(W)(V)O(d)).

If ∉d{-w0,…,-wn} then there exists a unique i such that -wi>d>-w+i1 (for notation, =-w-1∞ and =-w+n1-∞). The spectral sequence from Corollary 1.4(3) for computing ⁢ΦW1(⁢O(d)) consists of two (possibly empty) strands A and B where

Math.text: A _ j = cases@(((O * (- w _ j)) tensor-product H ^ i) * open-interval@(P ^ n, E _ j * d), [ if ] * j element-of closed-interval@(0, i), 0, [ else])
A _ j
absent = cases@(((O * (- w _ j)) tensor-product H ^ i) * open-interval@(P ^ n, E _ j * d), [ if ] * j element-of closed-interval@(0, i), 0, [ else])
B _ j = cases@(((O * (- w _ j)) tensor-product H ^ (i + 1)) * open-interval@(P ^ n, E _ j * d), [ if ] * j element-of closed-interval@(i + 1, n), 0, [ else])
B _ j
absent = cases@(((O * (- w _ j)) tensor-product H ^ (i + 1)) * open-interval@(P ^ n, E _ j * d), [ if ] * j element-of closed-interval@(i + 1, n), 0, [ else])

para.p: The E2-page of this spectral sequence yields the ⁢GL(V)-equivariant short exact sequence

Math.text: 0 to kernel@(A) to (Phi ^ W) _ 1 * O * d to coker@(B) to 0

para.p: which we will show splits.

Let F be the EFW resolution of type =e(w0,w1,…,wi,d,w+i1,…,wn). We let A′ be the subcomplex of the sheafified complex ~F consisting of all terms in homological degrees 0,…,i, and we let B′ be the quotient complex of ~F consisting of all terms in homological degrees +i2,…,n.
Using (2.1), we see that =⁢λ(e)+i1⁢μ(W). Also, if ≤ki, then

Math.tex: \lambda(\mathbf{e})^{k}_{j}=\begin{cases}w_{n}-w_{j-1}-(n+1-j)&\text{if }j\leq k% \\ w_{n}-w_{j}-(n+1-j)&\text{if }k+1\leq j\leq i\\ w_{n}-d-(n-i)&\text{if }j=i+1\\ w_{n}-w_{j-1}-(n+1-j)&\text{ if }j>i+1\end{cases},
Math.text: lambda * (e ^ k) _ j = cases@(w _ n - w _ (j - 1) - (n + 1) - j, [if ] * j less= k, w _ n - w _ j - (n + 1) - j, [if ] * k + 1 less= j less= i, w _ n - d - n - i, [if ] * j = i + 1, w _ n - w _ (j - 1) - (n + 1) - j, [ if ] * j > i + 1)

para.p: and if ≥k+i2, then

Math.tex: \lambda(\mathbf{e})^{k}_{j}=\begin{cases}w_{n}-w_{j-1}-(n+1-j)&\text{if }j\leq i% +1\\ w_{n}-d-(n-i-1)&\text{if }j=i+2\\ w_{n}-w_{j-2}-(n+1-j)&\text{if }i+3\leq j\leq k\\ w_{n}-w_{j}-(n+1-j)&\text{ if }j>k+1\end{cases}.
Math.text: lambda * (e ^ k) _ j = cases@(w _ n - w _ (j - 1) - (n + 1) - j, [if ] * j less= i + 1, w _ n - d - n - i - 1, [if ] * j = i + 2, w _ n - w _ (j - 2) - (n + 1) - j, [if ] * i + 3 less= j less= k, w _ n - w _ j - (n + 1) - j, [ if ] * j > k + 1)

para.p: Recall that =Ej⁢⊗⁢S⁢λ(w)j(Q*)O(-wnn) where =w(w0,…,wn). It follows from Borel–Weil–Bott (Theorem 2.3) that ≅A′k⁢⊗⁢O(-wk)Hi(Pn,⁢Ek(d)) for =k0,…,i, and that ≅B′k⁢⊗⁢O(-wk)H+i1(Pn,⁢Ek(d)) for =k+i2,…,n. Both complexes are ⁢GL(V)-equivariant, and the differentials in the EFW complex are uniquely determined by the condition that they are ⁢GL(V)-equivariant (a consequence of Pieri’s rule, see for example [SW, §1.2]), so we deduce that ≅A′A and ≅B′B.
In particular, this implies that we have 0→B′→⁢⊗⁢S⁢μ(W)(V)O(d)→A′→0, and since ≅BB′ and ≅AA′, there is an extension coming from ~F:

Math.text: 0 to coker@(B) to ((S _ (mu * W) * V) tensor-product O) * d to kernel@(A) to 0.

para.p: Note that the positions of kerA and cokerB are reversed in (5.6) and (5.7).

Since (5.6) and (5.7) are both equivariant extensions, we may apply Lemma 5.4 to conclude that the sequence in (5.6) splits. Let ∈ηExt1(kerA,cokerB) be the class of the extension (5.7). We let G be the family of bundles on ×PnA1 where over ∈tA1, the bundle Gt is the extension corresponding to ⁢tη. This bundle satisfies the conditions of the lemma.

Finally, we note that if >d-w0, then =A∙0 and =kerA0, so ⁢ΦW1(⁢O(d))≅cokerB≅⁢⊗⁢S⁢μ(W)(V)O(d). A similar thing happens when <d-wn with the roles of A and B reversed. So in these cases, the bundle G is simply ⁢O(d)NW. ∎
For (1): we compute that

Math.text: H ^ i * open-interval@(P ^ n, (Phi ^ W) _ 2 * F * d) = H ^ i * open-interval@(P ^ n, ((p _ (list@(2, *)) * (U _ W tensor-product (p _ 1) ^ *) * F) tensor-product O) * d)
H ^ i * open-interval@(P ^ n, (Phi ^ W) _ 2 * F * d)
absent = H ^ i * open-interval@(P ^ n, ((p _ (list@(2, *)) * (U _ W tensor-product (p _ 1) ^ *) * F) tensor-product O) * d)
absent = H ^ i * open-interval@(P ^ n, p _ (list@(2, *)) * (((U _ W tensor-product (p _ 1) ^ *) * F) tensor-product O) * open-interval@(0, d))
absent = H ^ i * open-interval@(P ^ n, p _ (list@(2, *)) * (((U _ W tensor-product (p _ 1) ^ *) * F) tensor-product O) * open-interval@(0, d))
absent = H ^ i * open-interval@(Delta _ W, (((U _ W tensor-product (p _ 1) ^ *) * F) tensor-product O) * open-interval@(0, d))
absent = H ^ i * open-interval@(Delta _ W, (((U _ W tensor-product (p _ 1) ^ *) * F) tensor-product O) * open-interval@(0, d))
evaluated-at@([(] * p _ 2, Delta _ W) * [ is affine)]
absent = H ^ i * open-interval@(P ^ n, p _ (list@(1, *)) * ((U _ W * open-interval@(0, d)) tensor-product (p _ 1) ^ *) * F)
absent = H ^ i * open-interval@(P ^ n, p _ (list@(1, *)) * ((U _ W * open-interval@(0, d)) tensor-product (p _ 1) ^ *) * F)
evaluated-at@([(] * p _ 1, Delta _ W) * [ is affine)]
absent = H ^ i * open-interval@(P ^ n, (p _ (list@(1, *)) * U _ W * open-interval@(0, d)) tensor-product F)
absent = H ^ i * open-interval@(P ^ n, (p _ (list@(1, *)) * U _ W * open-interval@(0, d)) tensor-product F)
absent = H ^ i * open-interval@(P ^ n, ((Phi ^ W) _ 1 * O * d) tensor-product F)
absent = H ^ i * open-interval@(P ^ n, ((Phi ^ W) _ 1 * O * d) tensor-product F)

para.p: Let G be the vector bundle over ×PnA1 constructed in Lemma 5.5. Let :q→×PnA1Pn be the projection map. Then ⁢⊗Gq*F is flat over A1 with special fiber ⊗⁢ΦW1(⁢O(d))F and general fiber ⁢F(d)⊕NW since ≅(⁢⊗Gq*F)t⊗GtF. So semicontinuity and the above computation imply:

Math.text: h ^ i * open-interval@(P ^ n, (Phi ^ W) _ 2 * F * d) = h ^ i * open-interval@(P ^ n, ((Phi ^ W) _ 1 * O * d) tensor-product F) >= h ^ i * open-interval@(P ^ n, F * d ^ (direct-sum N _ W))

para.p: When ∈d{-w0,…,-wn}, or >d-w0, or <d-wn, the sheaf G is constant over A1, so we get equality in the above formula. ∎
Note that ⁢⊗EWp2*F looks like:

Math.text: ((O * (- w _ 0)) boxtimes E _ 0) tensor-product F leftarrow dots leftarrow ((O * (- w _ n)) boxtimes E _ n) tensor-product F leftarrow 0.

para.p: The Castelnuovo–Mumford regularity of a supernatural sheaf with roots -f1≥-f2≥…≥-fn is +-f11. Hence

Math.text: reg@(E _ i) = cases@((- w _ 0) + 1, [ if ] * i not-equals 0, (- w _ 1) + 1, [ if ] * i = 0.)

para.p: It then follows from [Laz, Prop. 1.8.9] that

Math.text: reg@(E _ i tensor-product F) less= cases@((- w _ 0) + 1 + w _ 0 = 1, [ if ] * i not-equals 0, (- w _ 1) + 1 + w _ 0 less 1, [ if ] * i = 0.)

para.p: In particular, ⊗EiF has no higher cohomology for all i, and thus the only nonzero terms in the E1-page of the spectral sequence for ΦW1 appear in the H0-row. The E1-page of that spectral sequence is thus a locally free resolution of ⁢ΦW1(F) which has the form

Math.text: ((O * (- w _ 0)) tensor-product H ^ 0) * open-interval@(P ^ n, E _ 0 tensor-product F) leftarrow dots leftarrow ((O * (- w _ n)) tensor-product H ^ 0) * open-interval@(P ^ n, E _ n tensor-product F) leftarrow 0

para.p: and hence is the desired pure resolution. ∎
Note that Example 4.3 gives an example of Corollary 1.5.
In this section, we prove our main application to Boij–Söderberg decompositions.
The spectral sequence ^E1p,q for ⁢ΦW2(F) has terms ⊗⁢Hi(Pn,⁢F(-wi))Ei on the main diagonal, and all other terms are 0. Next, note that in the Boij–Söderberg decomposition

Math.text: gamma * F = ((sum _ (i = 0)) ^ n)@(a _ i * gamma * E _ i)

para.p: the only contribution to the cohomology table in degree -wi comes from Ei which has =⁢hi(Pn,⁢Ei(-wi))NW by Theorem 1.1(2). It follows that

Math.text: h ^ i * open-interval@(P ^ n, F * (- w _ i)) = a _ i cdot N _ W

para.p: Hence, the spectral sequence ^E1p,q has terms Ei⊕⋅NWai along the main diagonal, and all other terms are 0. It follows immediately that ⁢ΦW2(F) has a filtration of the desired form.

For the claim about the cohomology table of ⁢ΦW2(F), we note that the given filtration of ⁢ΦW2(F) yields an upper bound of ∑=i0n⁢NWaiγ(Ei) on the cohomology table of ⁢Φ2W(F); this is because cohomology tables are subadditive with respect to short exact sequences. The lower bound is given by Proposition 5.1. ∎
We now return to Example 1.8. Here =W{O,⁢O(-2),⁢O(-3)} and we have

Math.text: gamma * F = gamma * E _ 2 + (1 / 3) * gamma * E _ 1

para.p: where =E2Q* and =E1⁢(Sym2Q*)(1). Theorem 1.9 proves that ⁢ΦW2(F) is an extension

Math.text: 0 to E _ 1 to (Phi ^ W) _ 2 * F to (E _ 2) ^ (direct-sum 3) to 0.

para.p: However, the extension splits as claimed:
In the second step we used that ≅Q⁢Q*(1) and Pieri’s rule for tensoring Schur functors, and in the third step we used Borel–Weil–Bott (Theorem 2.3). ∎eg
Note that while Corollary 1.10 is a special case of Theorem 1.9, its proof does not require the use of Proposition 5.1. ∎rmk

It is natural to ask whether these techniques can be used to categorify the Boij–Söderberg decomposition of an arbitrary vector bundle. For instance, one might hope for an iterative procedure in which a new W can be introduced for each step of the Boij–Söderberg decomposition. There are two challenges to this approach in general: finding the correct hypotheses for when the cohomology table of ⁢ΦW2(F) is a scalar multiple of the cohomology table of F, and finding a map from ⁢ΦW2(F) to the appropriate supernatural bundle that is surjective on cohomology. Though these both appear to be nontrivial problems, there is also room for optimism, as we know of no fundamental obstacles to such an approach working in general. ∎rmk
